NEW EARTH AND NEW HEAVEN
After persecuting sinners; God will make a new heaven and new earth ‘As
the new heavens and the new earth that I make will endure before me,’
declares the Lord. ‘So, will your name and descendants endure,’ ‘Then I
saw a new heaven and a new earth, for the first heaven and the first
earth had passed away, and there was no longer any sea. I saw the Holy
City, the New Jerusalem, coming down out of heaven from God, prepared
as a bride beautifully dressed for her husband. And I heard a loud voice
from the throne saying: ‘Now the dwelling of God is with men, and he will
live with them. They will be his people, and God himself will be with them
and be their God. He will wipe every tear from their eyes. There will be no
more death or mourning or crying or pain, for the old order of things has
passed away.’ He who was seated on the throne said, ‘I am making
everything new!’ Then he said, ‘write this down, for these words are
trustworthy and true (Revelation 21: 1-5).’ This is the day many Christians
around the world are anxiously waiting for; we are all saying: ‘THY
KINGDOM COME!!!
39
CHAPTER 5
THY WILL BE DONE
‘THY WILL BE DONE ON EARTH AS IT IS IN HEAVEN.’ Remember that I
mentioned that the Lord’s Prayer is like a tiered steps. The first step leads
you to the second one; the same applies here. This chapter is
interconnected with the previous one: ‘THY KINGDOM COME.’ People
must enter God’s Kingdom before they are taught to do his will. This is in
line with Jesus last words before he ascended to Heaven in Mathew 28: 18-
20 which says: ‘then Jesus came to them and said: all authority in Heaven
and on earth has been given to me. Therefore go and make disciples of all
nations, baptizing them in the name of the Father, and of the Son and of
the Holy Spirit, and teaching them to obey everything I have commanded
you.’
In His opening statement Jesus is defining the territory of his Kingdom
which stretches from Heaven and on earth. Secondly, he is instructing them
to baptize His disciples in the name of the Father, and of the Son and of the
Holy Spirit; and then teach them to obey everything he had commanded
them. What he commanded them to do is his will. A Kingdom might be
having many districts but all those districts will be having one King and same
laws. Hence Jesus is saying: ‘All authority in Heaven and on earth has been
given to me.’ So, Jesus is having his subjects in Heaven and here on earth. In
Heaven there are angels, living creatures, elders, and etcetera. They are
doing His will. Similarly, we as God’s children must also do his will. Like a
citizen of any country who must abide by the rules of that country we must
40
abide by the rules of Heaven which are disclosed to us. There is His will
which is a Heavenly secret. We should respect that. ‘The secret things
belong to the Lord our God, but the things revealed belong to us and to our
children forever, that we may follow the words of this law (Deuteronomy
29: 29).’ This scripture tells us that there are secrets which belong to our
God; which we are not going to discuss.
The most important thing is to surrender our lives to Him as obedient
children. We must not blame Him when He imposes His will upon us; even
if it seems to be unfair. We must trust His judgment above our own. This
reminds me of Jesus prayer at the Mount of Olives when His time to be
crucified was approaching. Luke 22: 41-42 say: ‘Then He went off from
them about the distance of a stone throw and knelt down and prayed.
‘Father,’ he said: ‘if you will, take this cup of suffering away from me. Not
my will, however, but your will be done.’ Jesus was facing an excruciating
experience of being humiliated and crucified for our sins. Although he
knew about it because it was prophesied by many prophets, but He didn’t
face the agony without fear. That is why He had to pray hard for this
painful phase. However, His words were well chosen. In spite of the
unbearable experience He had to go through, he respected God’s will.
Unlike all of us, Jesus knew what was about to happen to Him, and the
reward He would get for His sufferings. It was His destiny. Joseph; the son
of Jacob had to be sold to the Ishmaelites who took him to Egypt, and who
also sold him to Potiphar- one of the king’s officers, who was the captain of
the palace guard. He ended up being a personal servant of Potiphar. Unlike
in the case of Jesus Christ; God did not reveal to Joseph that he had to go
through that painful experience before his dreams are fulfilled. However
he faced his karma without questioning God. It was at the end that he
realized that going to Egypt was his destiny towards the fulfillment of his
dreams. This is a lesson we should all learn. We should not only say:’ THY
WILL BE DONE. IN EARTH AS IT IS DONE IN HEAVEN,’ but also respect
those words.
41
Many prophets and spiritual leaders from Moses to the Apostles wrote at
length about God’s will which I am not going to outline here. Nevertheless,
I’ve selected the following laws: Honor and praise His name, Sabbath and
Love.
HONOR AND PRAISE HIS NAME
Of all creations, man happens to be the only being after God’s image and
that rates him to be the most favored. ‘Then God said: ‘now we will make
human beings; they will be like Us and resemble Us. They will have power
over the fish, the birds, and all animals, domestic and wild (Genesis 1:26).’
That’s why He wants us to worship Him. We have responsibility to honor
and praise His name just like angels do in Heaven. We are not in this world
to please ourselves by eating and doing what we like only, but also to
honor, worship Him and obey His laws. By doing that we are
acknowledging Him as our God, our Father and our King. ‘You servants of
the Lord, praise His name! May His name be praised, now and forever.
From the East to the West praise the name of the Lord. The Lord rules over
all nations; His glory is above the Heaven (Psalms 113: 3-4).’ The above
scripture instruct all servants of the Lord to praise Him. We are not only His
children but His servant too. We are expected to fear Him and carry His
orders. Failure to do so is a sin in itself. That is why Malachi 1: 6 says: ‘the
almighty says to the priests: ‘a son honors his father, and a servant honors
his master. If I am your Father- where is the honor due to me? If I am a
master, where is the respect due to me?’ The fact that He is addressing this
message to the priest does not mean that it exclude other people. He is
referring to the priest because they were bearers of His word. In fact they
are supposed to convey this message to the people.
42
SABBATH
Sabbath was the most important day during the ancient Israelites. Exodus
31: 12-14 says: ‘Then the Lord said to Moses: ‘say to the Israelites: you
must observe my Sabbaths. This will be a sign between me and you for the
generations to come, so you may know that I am the Lord, who makes you
holy. Observe the Sabbath, because it is holy to you. Anyone who
desecrates it must be put to death, whoever does any work on that day
must be cut off from his people. For six days, work is to be done, but the
seventh day is a Sabbath of rest, holy to the Lord. Whoever does any work
on the Sabbath day must be put to death. The Israelites are to observe the
Sabbath, celebrating it for the generations to come as a lasting covenant. It
will be a sign between me and the Israelites forever, for in six days the Lord
made Heavens and the earth, and on the seventh day abstained from work
and rested.’ God instructed Moses to tell the Israelites to observe the
Sabbath.
According to the above quoted scripture, God was not talking to the whole
world; he was specifically directing his instruction to the Israelites who
were the chosen nation by that time. The Israelites were very strict and
cautious about Sabbath. Because of that instruction a man was stoned to
death for breaking the law of the Sabbath. Numbers 15: 32-36 say: ‘while
the Israelites were in the desert, a man was found gathering woods on the
Sabbath day. Those who found him gathering woods brought him to Moses
and Aaron and the whole assembly, and they kept him in custody, because
it was not clear what should be done to him. Then the Lord said to Moses:
the man must die. The whole assembly must stone him outside the camp.
So the assembly took him outside the camp and stoned him to death, as
the Lord commanded Moses.’ This is how important the Sabbath day was
to Israelites. Even today the Israelites still observe the Sabbath day
assiduously. On the Sabbath day the whole country comes to a standstill;
no work is allowed.
43
The question is: is the Sabbath day important to Israelites only? Sabbath
day is unheeded nowadays; only a small portion of the Christian
community around the world observe the Sabbath day. May be we should
first look at why did God Himself excluded other nations and instructed
Moses to tell the Israelites only to observe the Sabbath day. When God
told Moses to tell the Israelites to observe the Sabbath day He said: ‘the
Sabbath day is ‘holy to the Lord.’ He went on to explain why it is ‘holy to
Him’ by saying: ‘for six days the Lord made Heavens and the earth, and on
the seventh day abstained from work and rested.’ Most importantly: God
Himself rested on the seventh day which He later named Sabbath.
Genesis 2: 1-4: ‘thus the heavens and the earth were completed in their
vast array. By the seventh day God had finished the work he had been
doing, so on the seventh day He rested from all his work. And God
blessed the seventh day and made it holy, because on it, He rested from
all the work of creating that He had done. This is the account of the
heavens and the earth when they were created.’ So, Sabbath is a sacred
day even for God Himself. That is why he told the Israelites to rest in
celebration of the creation of heaven and earth. So, Sabbath day is not
only important to Israelites but to the international Christian community
because God made it holy.
Then, why did God instructed Moses to tell only the Israelites to observe
Sabbath. Let’s look at Ephesians 2: 12 which says: ‘remember that at that
time you were separate from Christ, excluded from the citizenship in
Israel and foreigners to the covenants of the promise, without hope and
without God in the world, but now in Christ Jesus you who once were far
away have been brought near through the blood of Christ.’ Firstly, we
were not under his Kingdom. As the above scripture say: ‘separate from
Christ, we were foreigners to the covenants, without hope and without
44
God in the world; that is why God instructed Moses to tell the Israelites
only to observe Sabbath. The situation is different now. Galatians 3: 26-28
say: ‘you are all sons of God through faith in Christ Jesus. For all of you
who are baptized into Christ have clothed yourselves with Christ. There is
neither Jew nor Greek, slaves nor free, male nor female, for you are all
one in Christ Jesus.’ The same Jesus Christ who said: ‘the Sabbath was
made for man, not man for the Sabbath. So the Son of Man is Lord even
of the Sabbath (Mark 2: 27-28).’ It is like saying: it is a person who must
sit on the chair, not a chair which must sit on a person. If Sabbath will still
be observed in the new heavens and new earth which God is yet to
create, why do present Christian community unheeded it. ‘As the new
heavens and the new earth that I make will endure before me,’ declares
the Lord. ‘So will your name and descendants endure. From one New
Moon to another and from one Sabbath to another, all mankind will
come and bow down before me,’ says the Lord. And they will go out and
look upon the dead bodies of those who rebelled against me, their worm
will not die, nor will their fire be quenched, and they will be loathsome to
all mankind (Isaiah 66:22-24). That is why he told the Israelites to rest in
celebration of the creation of heaven and earth.
So, Sabbath day is not only important to Israelites but to the international
Christian community. When we recite the Lord’s Prayer we all say: ‘THY
WILL BE DONE.’ Observing Sabbath is God’s will. This is what God want us
to do.
45
LOVE YOUR NEIGHBOUR
Love is one of the most important laws. There are numerous scriptures in
the bible talking about love. Even Jesus himself spoke about it at Mathew
35: 22-40 which says: ‘one of them, an expert in the law, tested him with
the question: teacher, which is the greatest commandment in the law?’’
Jesus replied: love the Lord your God with all your heart and with all your
soul and with all your mind. This is the first and greatest commandment.
And the second is like it: love your neighbor as yourself. All the law and the
prophets hang on these two commandments.’ The love of God will enable
one to adhere to his rules as John 14: 15 says: ‘If you love me, you will
obey what I command.’
The love of your neighbor will shield many sins like, jealousy, hatred,
gossiping murder, and etcetera. Jesus elaborated on this statement of
loving your neighbor as yourself at Luke 10: 29-37 which says: ‘but he
wanted to justify himself, so he asked Jesus: and who is my neighbor?’ In
reply Jesus said: ‘a man was going down from Jerusalem to Jericho, when
he fell in into the hands of robbers. They stripped him off his clothes, beat
him and went away, leaving him half dead. A priest happened to be going
down the same road, and when he saw the man, he passed by on the other
side. So too, a Levite, when he came to the place and saw him, passed by
on the other side; but a Samaritan, as he travelled, came where the man
was, and when he saw him, he took pity on him. He went to him and
bandaged his wounds, pouring on oil and wine. Then he put the man on his
own donkey, took him to an inn and took care of him. The next day he took
out two silver coins and gave them to the innkeeper. Look after him, he
said. And when I return, I will reimburse you for any extra expense you
may have. Which of these three do you think was a neighbor to the man
who fell into the hands of robbers? The expert in the law replied: the one
who had mercy on him. Jesus told him: go and do likewise. ’This parable by
46
Jesus Christ is telling us to do the same to the needy.
In Proverbs 19: 17 the Lord says: ‘he who is kind to the poor lends to the
Lord, and he will reward him for what he has done.’ The Lord hears the
prayers of the poor. He hears them when they pour their heart to him in
their destitution. Their tears fall on him; that is why any act of kindness will
never go unnoticed. That is why the bible says: when you help the poor or
the needy you are lending the Lord. Why? Because they are his
responsibility; so by helping them you’ve taken God’s responsibility.
That is why he will surely reward you. When you help the poor you are like
somebody who is investing. You are not investing in a fly by night scheme
or a get rich quick scheme. You are investing in the Almighty God. Because
you’ve shown mercy to the needy, so, God will show you mercy. ‘Blessed
are the merciful, for they will be shown mercy (Mathew 5: 7).’In Mathew 6:
19-20 Jesus says: ‘do not store up for yourselves treasures on earth, where
moth and rust destroy, and where thieves break in and steal. But store up
for yourselves treasures in Heaven, where thieves do not break in and
steal.’
There are individuals and organizations like the home base care group that
are doing acts of kindness to the needy like street kids, orphans, sick and
neglected people. Although they are earning to survive; but they are
earning barely enough to meet their basic needs, but they are working
earnestly to help the needy. I interviewed one of them while I was still
working with the community working programme and I discovered that
they are getting a small stipend and sometimes they don’t get anything
because of financial constraint. Most of their clients are neglected old
pensioners living in rickety mud houses. They clean their client’s houses
and make sure that they take their medication regularly. May the Lord
Almighty God, bless such people abundantly.
47
CHAPTER 6
GIVE US THIS DAY OUR DAILY BREAD
What does the inclusion of this statement: ‘GIVE US THIS DAY OUR DAILY
BREAD’ mean in the life of a Christian? It means that as much as God
cares for our spiritual welfare, He also cares for our physical needs. As we
proceed with this prayer we should not lose sight of the introductory part
of the prayer i.e. ‘OUR FATHER.’ If He is our Father we must put our trust
in Him to be able to provide for our daily needs.
That’s why He emphasizes that GIVE US ‘THIS DAY’ OUR DAILY BREAD.
‘THIS DAY’ in this sentence means we should only ask him to provide for
that specific day and not worry ourselves about tomorrow because He
will take care of tomorrow. He wants us to believe that He is able to take
care of our daily needs. He knows that we must eat while we are still in
this physical body; however we should focus on His Kingdom which is
eternal. The message of this sentence is similar to what He said at
Mathew 6: 25-34 which read as follows: ‘Therefore I say to you, do not
worry about your life, what you will eat or what you will drink, nor about
your body, what you will put on. Is not life more than food and the body
more than clothing? Look at the birds of the air, for they neither saw nor
reap nor gather into barns, yet your heavenly Father feeds them. Are you
not of more value than they? Which of you by worrying can add one cubic
of his statue? So why do you worry about clothing? Consider the lilies of
48
the field, how they grow. They neither toil nor spin, and yet I say to you
that not even Solomon in all his glory was arrayed like one of these. Now
if God so clothes the grass of the field, which today is, and tomorrow is
thrown into the oven, will He not more clothe you, O you of little faith?
Therefore do not worry, saying, what shall we eat? Or what shall we
drink? O what shall we wear? For after all these things the gentiles seek.
For your Heavenly Father knows that you need all these things. But seek
first the Kingdom of God and His righteousness, and all these things shall
be added to you. Therefore do not worry about tomorrow, for tomorrow
will worry about its own things. Sufficient for the day is its own trouble.’
Jesus knows that our physical bodies will need food every day. Hence he
said ‘GIVE US THIS DAY OUR DAILY BREAD. ‘Daily’ in this sentence means
he knows that our bodies will need bread daily; but we should ask God to
give us bread for ‘THIS DAY.’ And in Mathew 6: 25 he says: ‘Therefore I
tell you, do not worry about your life, what you will eat or drink----.’
He wants us to worry about his Kingdom; that’s why he went on to say: ‘But
seek first his Kingdom and his righteousness.’ If we are righteous and steady
in our faith, all these things will be added to us. That’s why he went on to
say: ‘O you of little faith? So do not worry, saying: what shall we eat? Or
what shall we wear? For the pagans run after all these things, and your
heavenly Father knows that you need them. But seek first his Kingdom and
his righteousness, and all these things will be added to you as well.’ This
prayer is mainly for God’s children who have accepted Jesus. I reiterate my
statement that this prayer is interconnected like tiered steps. It is about
God’s Kingdom and his righteousness. Jesus separate his children from
Gentiles who only run after what they will eat or drink and disregard his
Kingdom. Our hearts should focus on God’s Kingdom just like what Paul said
at Colossians 3: 1-4 when said: ‘since, then, you have been raised with
Christ, set your hearts on things above, where Christ is seated at the right
49
hand of God. Set your minds on things above, not on earthly things. For you
died, and your life is now hidden with Christ in God; when Christ, who is
your life, appears, then you also will appear with him in glory.’
Now, if God can provide for our daily bread why do we have to work? Does
this prayer negate the punishment He imposed on Adam when He said: ‘by
the sweat of your brow you will eat your food until you return to the
ground, since from it you were taken, for dust you are and to dust you will
return (Genesis 3:19)’? No, we still have to work. Let’s look at Mathew 6: 33.
It reads as follows: ‘but seek first the Kingdom of God and His righteousness,
and all these things shall be added to you.’ It says: if we seek the Kingdom of
God and His righteousness; what we will eat, drink and wear shall be ADDED
to us.
That means He will add to what you’ve worked for just like He blessed
seven loaves of bread and a few small fish and fed four thousand people
besides women and children. Let’s look at the scripture and see why Jesus
fed them. As we visit the scripture we should bear in mind what Jesus said:
‘but seek first the Kingdom of God and His righteousness, and all these
things shall be added to you.’ ‘Jesus called His disciples to Him and said: ‘I
have compassion for these people; they have already been with me for
three days and have nothing to eat. I do not want to send them away
hungry, or they may collapse on the way.’ It is amazing that the crowd had
been with Jesus on the mountainside for three days without even thinking
about their homes and their daily chores they left at home. Moreover they
had nothing to eat for those three days. What happened to them? The
bible say: ‘the people were amazed when they saw the mute speaking, the
crippled made well, the lame walking and the blind seeing. So, their hearts
were set on the glory of God they were witnessing through Jesus. Then,
fulfilled is the scripture which say: ‘for where your treasure is, there your
heart will be also.’ Then, we have an answer why did those people forgot
their homes and food; it is because they were marveling at their newly
50
found treasure which is King Jesus. That is why they ended up ‘PRAISING
THE GOD OF ISRAEL.’
Their minds were centered on praising God. They did not worry about
eating and drinking; they even forgot about their homes. Those people did
exactly what Jesus is teaching us to do when he says: ‘therefore I say to
you, do not worry about your life, what you will eat or what you will drink,
nor about your body, what you will put on. Is not life more than food and
the body more than clothing?’ And because our Lord and savior Jesus
Christ is honest and will never go back on his word as Numbers 23: 19 says:
‘God is not a man, that he should lie, nor a son of man, that he should
change his mind. Does he speak and then not act? Does he promise and
not fulfill?’ He made a promise that: ‘but seek first the Kingdom of God and
His righteousness, and all these things shall be added to you.’ The crowd
did their part of seeking first the Kingdom of God and His righteousness.
What did Jesus do? ‘Now Jesus called His disciples to Himself and said: ‘’I
have compassion on the multitude, because they have now continued
with me three days and have nothing to eat. And I do not want to send
them away hungry, lest they faint on the way.’’ His disciples said to Him:
‘’where could we get enough bread in the wilderness to fill such a great
multitude.’’ Jesus said to them: ‘’how many loaves do you have?’’ And
they said: ‘’seven and a few little fish.’’ So He commanded the multitude
to sit down on the ground. And He took the seven loaves and the fish and
gave thanks, broke them and gave them to His disciples, and the disciples
gave to the multitude. So they all ate and were filled, and they took up
seven large baskets full of the fragments that were left. Now those who
ate were four thousand men, besides women and children. Jesus did as
He promised that: ‘but seek first the Kingdom of God and His
righteousness, and all these things shall be ADDED to you.’ Because the
multitude did their part; He was honest to do His part of providing them
51
with something to eat. What Jesus did is to bless the seven loaves of
bread and a few little fish; and those multiply to feed the multitude. Now,
back to our question: If the Lord’s Prayer says: ‘give us this day our daily
bread;’ does it means we do not have to work? No! We still have to work
as we can see that Jesus blessed what they had. This signifies that you get
nothing from nothing.
Another typical example that God expect us to work is found at Mathew
25: 14-30 which read as follows: ‘again, it will be like a man going on a
journey, who called his servants and entrusted his property to them. To
one he gave five talents of his money, to another two talents, and to
another one talent, each according to his ability. Then he went on his
journey. The man who had received the five talents went at once and put
his money to work and gained five more. So also, the one with two
talents gained two more. But the man who had received the one talent
went off, dug a hole in the ground and hid his master’s money. After a
long time the master of those servants returned and settled accounts
with them. The man who had received five talents brought the other five.
‘Master, he said: ‘you entrusted me with five talents. See, I have gained
five more. His master replied: ‘well done, good and faithful servant! You
have been faithful with a few things. I will put you in charge of many
things. Come and share your master’s happiness!’ The man with the two
talents also came. ‘Master, he said: ‘you entrusted me with two talents;
see I have gained two more.’ His master replied: ‘well done, good and
faithful servant! You have been faithful with a few things; I will put you in
charge of many things. Come and share your master’s happiness!’ Then
the man who had received the one talent came. ‘Master,’ he said: ‘I knew
that you are a hard man, harvesting where you have not sown and
gathering where you have not scattered seed. So I was afraid and went
52
out and hid your talent in the ground. See, here is what belongs to you.’
His master replied: ‘you wicked lazy servant! So you knew that I harvest
where I have not sown and gather where I have not scattered seed?
Well then, you should have put my money on deposit with the bankers,
so that when I returned I would have received it back with interest. ‘Take
the talent from him and give it to the one has the ten talents. For
everyone who has will be given more and he will have abundance.
Whoever does not have, even what he has will be taken from him. And
throw that worthless servant outside, into the darkness, where there will
be weeping and gnashing of teeth.’ Then, what does this parable tells us?
It means as human beings we are blessed with different talents. So,
instead of folding our arms we should harness and develop our talents in
order to bear more fruits which will benefit the society. We should do
self-introspection in order to identify our talents; in that way we can hone
them in order to be useful to the society. In most cases the plateau is not
crowded with talented people but with hard workers. Ephesians 4: 28
says: ‘He who has been stealing must steal no longer, but must work,
doing something useful with his hands, that he may have something to
share with those in need.’
The bible is very clear on encouraging people to work hard. ‘He who
works hard will have plenty of bread, but he who follows worthless
pursuits will have plenty of poverty’ (Proverbs 28:19 ESV / 96). ‘For even
when we were with you, we would give you this command: If anyone is
not willing to work, let him not eat’ (2 Thessalonians 3:10). ‘But if anyone
does not provide for his relatives, and especially for members of his
household, he has denied the faith and is worse than an unbeliever.’ (1
Timothy 5:8). It is therefore a responsibility of every Christian to work
hard to provide for their needs and for those around them.
53
Because we are God’s children we must involve Him in everything we do.
‘Commit to the Lord whatever you do, and your plans will succeed
(Proverbs 16: 3)’. Sometimes we fail because we don’t involve God in our
plans. Whether you are selling tomatoes, or you’re an employee, or artist,
or even a soccer player you should involve God in your undertaking. We
should remember that he made a promise that: ‘you may ask me for
anything in my name, and I will do it (John 14: 14). God is honest and
always keep His promise. But like any father He will treat us as His
children. As our hearts are open to our children who obey our commands;
God do the same. He says: ‘but showing love to a thousand generations of
those who love me and keep my commandments (Exodus 20: 6). If we
don’t keep His commandments He will also ignore our prayers. Proverbs
1: 23-33 says: ‘if you had responded to my rebuke, I would have poured
out my heart to you and made my thoughts known to you. But since you
rejected me when I called and no one gave heed when I stretched out my
hand, since you ignored all my advice and would not accept my rebuke; I
in turn will laugh at your disaster; I will mock when calamity overtakes
you-when calamity overtakes you like a storm, when disaster sweeps over
you like a whirlwind, when distress and trouble overwhelm you. Then
they will call to me but I will not answer; they will look for me but will not
find me. Since they hated knowledge and did not choose to fear the Lord,
since they would not accept my advice and spurned my rebuke, they will
eat the fruit of their ways and be filled with the fruit of their schemes. For
the waywardness of the simple will kill them, and the complacency of
fools will destroy them; but whoever listens to me will live in safety and
be at ease, without fear of harm.’
54
CHAPTER 7
FORGIVE US OUR TRESPASSES. AS WE FORGIVE THEM
‘FORGIVE US OUR TRESPASSES, AS WE FORGIVE THEM,’ Jesus said as He
continued with the Lord’s Prayer. What does trespass mean? It means to
break the law; to do something wrong to somebody. In biblical terms to
trespass is to sin. Okay; let me cut to the chase. Sin has its origin back to
the era of Adam and Eve. ‘The Lord God took the man and put him in the
Garden of Eden to work it and take care of it. And the Lord God
commanded the man: ‘’you are free to eat from any tree in the garden;
but you must not eat from the tree of knowledge of good and evil, for
when you eat of it you will die (Genesis 2: 15-17). Adam and Eve ate from
the tree of knowledge of good and evil after being deceived by the
serpent. Adam and Eve broke the law God gave them and that was the
beginning of sin in human race. And sin gave birth to death. So, God sent
Jesus Christ who died on the cross thereby paying the penalty of sin which
is death for us. ‘For all have sinned and fall short of the glory of God, and
are justified freely by his grace through the redemption that came by
Christ Jesus. God presented him as a sacrifice of atonement, through faith
in his blood. He did this to demonstrate his justice, because in his
forbearance he had left the sins committed unpunished- he did it to
demonstrate his justice at the present time, so as to be just and the one
who justifies those who have faith in Jesus (Romans 3:23-26).’ Therefore
55
through him our sins can be forgiven.
Then, if we can be forgiven our sins through Jesus Christ it means
everyone can call the name of Jesus Christ and ask for forgiveness. Why
should I go to Church or consult another person to pray for me? I can go
for a drinking binge, commit adultery, steal, rape, murder, and etcetera.
The next day I wake up from my bed; remember that I have sinned in
front of God and human kind; then, kneel down next to my bed and call
on the name of Jesus Christ and asked him to forgive me. The question is:
will I be forgiven? If not; why? I mean I have asked forgiveness in the
name of Jesus Christ who shed his blood for us. No, this is not how sins
are forgiven.
JESUS’ DELEGATION OF AUTHORITY
God’s Kingdom operates in more or less in similar way like Kingdoms of
this world. At the top of the hierarchy there is the president. Next to him
are ministers, director generals, and etcetera to whom he delegates his
authority. The same applies to God’s Kingdom. Jesus came to this world,
died for our sins, rose from the dead and ascended to heaven. Before He
ascended to heaven He appointed the twelve apostles to represent him in
the twelve tribes of Israel. Before He ascended to heaven he said to
them: ‘peace to you! As the Father had sent Me, I also send you.’ And
when he had said this, He breathed on them, and said to them: ‘’Receive
the Holy Spirit. If you forgive the sins of any, they are forgiven them, if
you retain the sins of any, they are retained (John 20: 21-23). In that way
HE was anointing them with the Holy Spirit; empowering them to forgive
sins. That is why we need to confess our sins as James 5: 1 6 say:
‘therefore confess your sins to each other and pray for each other so that
you may be healed.’ You don’t confess to anyone but to the elders of the
56
church who have been anointed with the Holy Spirit and given
responsibility to pray to God for the forgiveness of sins like Jesus did.
‘Whoever conceals their sins does not prosper, but the one who
confesses and renounces them finds mercy’ (Proverbs 28:13). So
forgiveness of sins is conditional to confession.
It is also expected of every Christian to participate in the feast of
unleavened bread, also known as communion. The blessed unleavened
bread is the symbol of the body of Christ and the blessed wine symbolize
His blood which has replaced the offerings of animals which were used in
the Old Testament. ‘While they were eating, Jesus took bread, gave
thanks and broke it, and gave it to his disciples, saying, ‘’Take and eat it;
this is my body.’’ Then he took the cup, gave thanks and offered it to
them, saying, ‘’Drink from it, all of you. This is my blood of the covenant,
which is poured out for many for the forgiveness of sins (Mathew: 26: 26-
27).’’ A person must do a thorough self-introspection before participating
in the feast of unleavened bread. You don’t participate in the feast if
there is a sin you’re afraid to confess. Anyone who participate in the feast
must be clean in body and in spirit because ‘whoever eats the bread or
drinks the cup of the Lord in an unworthy manner will be guilty of sinning
against the body and the blood of the Lord (1Corintheans 11: 27).
57
FORGIVE OTHERS
‘FORGIVE US OUR TRESPASSES, AS WE FORGIVE THEM.’ This statement is
indirectly putting a qualifying condition on getting forgiveness of our sins
from the Lord. It means before we ask forgiveness from God we must
start by forgiving those who wronged us. People usually say: what goes
around comes around. What does this saying mean? It means: what you
do to other people influence their actions towards you. In other words it
means that you’ll always get what you give others. You must love in order
to be loved; respect in order to be respected. If you hate and disrespect
people they will give you back what you gave them. ‘Do unto others as
you would like others to do to you’ is an old Christian principle. The same
applies with God. You can’t expect God to forgive your sins if you don’t
forgive others who wrong you. ‘Do not judge others or you will be judged.
For in the same way you judge others, you will be judged, and with the
measure you use, it will be measured to you (Mathew 7: 1).’ Then if we
expect God to forgive us our trespasses we must also forgive others.
A perfect example is given by Jesus at Mathew 18: 23-35: ‘therefore, the
Kingdom of Heaven is like a king who wanted to settle accounts with his
servants. As he began the settlement, a man who owed him ten thousand
talents was brought to him. Since he was not able to pay, the master
ordered that he and his wife and his children and all that he had to be
sold to repay the debt. That servant fell on his knees before him. ‘Be
58
patient with me,’ he begged, ‘and I will pay back everything.’ The
servant’s master took pity on him, cancelled the debt and let him go. But
when the servant went out, he found one of his fellow servants who
owed him a hundred denarii. He grabbed him and began to choke him.
‘Pay back what you owe me!’ he demanded. His fellow servant fell on his
knees and begged him, ‘be patient with me, and I will pay you back.’ But
he refused. Instead, he went off and had the man thrown into prison until
he could pay the debt. When the other servants saw what had happened,
they were greatly distressed and went and told their master everything
that had happened. Then the master called the servant in. ‘You wicked
servant,’ he said. ‘I cancelled all that debt of yours because you begged
me to. Shouldn’t you have had mercy on your fellow servant just as I had
on you?’ In anger his master turned him over to the jailers to be tortured,
until he should pay back all he owed. ‘This is how my heavenly Father will
treat each of you unless you forgive your brother or sister from your
heart.’ The wicked servant had already been forgiven the debt he owed,
but he couldn’t forgive the servant who owed him less what his master
had forgiven him. Because of that his debt was reinstated. What does this
parable means? It means if we don’t forgive those who wrong us our
Heavenly father will not forgive us our sins.
59
CHAPTER 8
LEAD US NOT INTO TEMPTATION BUT DELIVER US FROM EVIL
The above statement by Jesus as he continued with the Lord’s Prayer
might have caused confusion to many Christians and scholars. We can’t
avoid asking ourselves that: did Jesus actually say those words? ‘Lead us
not into temptation but deliver us from evil.’ What was Jesus implying
when he said those words? If you want to fully understand the exact
meaning of a speaker don’t cut him mid-sentence. If you do that you
might misunderstand him or her completely. The sentence has different
meaning if we interpret part of it. For example: if we say ‘lead us not into
temptation,’ the meaning differs from the meaning of the whole
sentence. It is like a parent when he tells his child: ‘don’t go to school
when it rains heavily.’ The sentence changes its meaning when we cut it
and say: ‘don’t go to school.’ In the latter sentence the child will not go to
school at all. With the first sentence the child will go to school if it does
not rains heavily. That is why we need to take our breath; listen until the
speaker finish speaking. It is then that we will interpret and make sense of
the whole sentence. The same applies here. If we interpret the first part it
will mean Jesus was implying that Christians should not be tempted.
Christians have always been tempted and will be tempted; even by God
Himself. If God loves you He will tempt you. One will only earn God’s trust
after overcoming trials. Trials are the way we score points to God.
Through trials our faith and love for our God become manifest. ‘Some
60
time later God tested Abraham. He said to Him: ‘Abraham!’
‘Here I am,’ he replied. Then God said: ‘take your son, your only son
Isaac, whom you love, and go to the region of Moriah. Sacrifice him there
as a burnt offering on one of the mountains I will tell you about
(Genesis 22: 1).’ After that Abraham did as God had instructed him to do.
In that way he earned God’s trust as it is written in Genesis 22: 12 that:
‘now I know that you fear God, because you have not withheld from me
your son, your only son.’ Sometimes it is the devil that tempts us; but it is
God who is giving him permission to do so.
Going back to our topic; ‘lead us not into temptation but deliver us from
evil.’ What does this statement mean? It means although God will tempt
us but He will deliver us from evil. How will He do that? He will only
subject you to a temptation which is equal to your faith. When God pit
you against a certain temptation it means He trust you not to disappoint
Him. He is guaranteeing with your faith to the devil himself. He will tell
the devil that this is my child. He will stand by me even if you can test him
with this kind of temptation he will never forsake me. The devil will tell
God that I can prove to you that he will stray in the face of trials. This is
what happened to Job. ‘When the day came for heavenly beings to
appear before the Lord, Satan was there among them. The Lord asked
him, ‘what have you been doing?’ Satan answered; I have been walking
here and there, roaming round the earth.’ ‘Did you notice my servant
Job?’ the Lord asked. ‘There is no one on earth as faithful and good as he
is. He worships me and is careful not to do anything evil.’ Satan replied,
‘would Job worship you if he got nothing out of it? You have always
protected him and his family and everything he owns. You blessed
everything he does, and you have given him enough cattle to fill the
whole country. But suppose you take away everything he has---he will
61
curse you to your face.’ ‘All right,’ the Lord said to Satan, ‘everything he
has is in your power, but you must not hurt Job himself (Job 1: 6-12).’ So
Satan left. Now we see God guaranteeing Job’s faith to Satan. God trust
that Job would not curse him even if everything he had could be taken
away from him. The devil denied that; and that caused God to allow Satan
to take everything Job had away from him. As a result Satan mercilessly
took everything Job had. God could not protect Job because of that
agreement. That adversity did not cause Job to sway away from God. If
God did not trust Job’s faith he wouldn’t have allowed Satan to take away
his wealth. Why? Because that would make him to turn to evil; that is
what Jesus meant when he said: ‘lead us not into temptation but deliver
us from evil.’ Paul clarified that at Corinthians 10: 13 when he said: ‘Every
test that you have experienced is the kind that normally comes to people.
But God keeps his promise, and He will not allow you to be tested beyond
your power to remain firm; at the time you are put to the test, He will
give you the strength to endure it, and so provide you with a way out.’
The most important thing for a Christian is to hold on to his or her faith
during trials. When you are going through trials God and His angels are
watching anxiously like spectators watching their favorite soccer club
playing, cheering and ululating as you conquer. Similarly He becomes
disappointed when you turn to evil in the face of trials. Imagine how God
would feel if Job was defeated by Satan. James 1: 12 says: ‘happy are
those who remain faithful under trials, because when they succeed in
passing such a test, they will receive as their reward the life which God
has promised to those who love him.’ Trials are like a ladder towards the
Kingdom of God. That is why: Acts 14:22 say: ‘they strengthened the
believers and encouraged them to remain true to their faith. We must
pass through many troubles to enter the Kingdom of God,’ they taught.
Just like we see golden earrings, golden watches, and etcetera being
62
displayed in jewelry shops; that gold has been tasted in fire before being
used. The same applies to us; we have to go through those difficulties
before we enter the Kingdom of Heaven. We must overcome evil in the
face of trials. 1 Peter 1: 6-7 say: ‘be glad about this, even though it may
now be necessary for you to be sad for a while because of the many kinds
of trials you suffer. Their purpose is to prove that your faith is genuine.
Even gold, which can be destroyed, is tested by fire, and so your faith,
which is much more precious than gold, must also be tested, so that it
may endure. Then you will receive praise and glory and honor on the day
when Jesus Christ is revealed.’ We need to emulate martyrs like Daniel,
Shadrach, Meshach, Abednego, Stephen, and etcetera who defended
their faith until death. Even our Lord and savior Jesus Christ had to
endure painful death by humiliation and finally crucifixion on the cross
before he was exulted to His Kingdom. Revelation 21: 7-8 say: ‘those who
win victory will receive this from me: I will be their God and they will be
my children. But cowards, traitors, perverts, murderers, the immoral,
those who practice magic, those who worship idols, and all liars---the
place of them is the lake burning with fire and Sulphur, which is the
second death.’
63
CHAPTER 9
FOR THINE IS THE KINGDOM, THE POWER, THE GLORY
I said that the Lord’s Prayer is like tiered steps; each step leads you to the
next one. ‘FOR THINE IS THE KINGDOM, THE POWER, And THE GLORY’ is
the plateau of the prayer. This closing statement is the symbol of faith in
our mighty God. We are telling Him that we do acknowledge ‘WHO He is.
When we say ‘THINE IS THE KINGDOM,’ we are implying that all the
kingdoms of this world belong to him. ‘THINE’ means yours. He is the king
of kings. The sentence continues to say: ‘THE POWER.’ It means He is
omnipotent. He is more powerful than all demons and idols which might
be hindering our progress. In Revelation 3: 7 He says: ‘These are the
words of him who is holy and true, who holds the key of David. What he
opens no one can shut, and what he shuts no one can open.’ He alone
deserves the ‘GLORY.’ He is the God almighty who is able to solve all our
problems. Those words are usually affirmed with confidence by the
person who is praying. This is the attitude we should embrace after we
have offloaded our problems to Him. For when we pray, we are
communicating with God. We know and believe that He is listening to our
prayers. Mathew 11: 28 say: ‘come to me, all of you who are tired from
carrying heavy loads and I will give you rest.’ Now, we have told Him what
was troubling us. We came to God with broken hearts; we were hopeless
64
and afraid, but we are now going with courage at the knowledge that our
God is having complete power to redeem us from any kind of adverse
situation we might be facing. We know that our Father in Heaven is the
owner of all Kingdoms; even the Kingdom of darkness. After giving God
our problems there is no need to fret. By praying we have given Him the
task of fighting our battle.
At Romans 8: 31-34 Paul said: ‘in view of all this, what can we say? If God
is for us, who can be against us? Certainly not God, who did not even
keep back his own Son---will he not also freely give us all things? Who can
accuse God’s chosen people? God himself declares them not guilty! Who
then, will condemn them? Not Christ Jesus, who died, or rather, who was
raised to life and is at the right- hand side of God, pleading with him for
us! When Paul said: ‘WHO can be against us?’ ‘WHO’ means everything;
even Kingdoms of this world cannot stand in God’s way when He decides
to defend His chosen people. Kingdom belongs to Him. Kings are part of
His creation; He enthrones and dethrones them at will. What is
impossible to us is possible to him. We are like ponds in the chess board
and He is a player.
Sometimes He uses your enemy to His advantage. We have seen what He
did to Joseph the son of Jacob. ‘Then Joseph had another dream and said
to his brothers: I had another dream, in which I saw the sun, the moon,
and eleven stars bowing down to me. He also told the dream to his
father, and his father scolded him: ‘what kind of a dream is that? Do you
think that your mother, your brothers, and I are going to come and bow
down to you (Genesis 37: 9-10)?’ His brothers sold him to Ishmaels where
he ended up in Egypt where he served as a slave for many years. His
brothers thought that all his dreams had been destroyed. Many years
65
later they bowed in front of him as he had dreamed. ‘Your humble
servant, our father, is still alive and well.’ And they knelt and bowed down
before him (Genesis 43:28). When his brothers sold him they thought
they were destroying his dreams; they didn’t know that God is using their
evil hearts to fulfill His plans of making Joseph their king. He is still the
same God today. If you believe and hold on steadfast on His word He will
make your enemy to bow down before you. ‘The LORD kills and restores
to life; he sends people to the world of the dead and brings them back
again (1Samuel 2: 6).’ We have seen that when Jesus brought Lazarus
who had been buried for four days back to life. He did that because he
wanted us to believe in his name. Whatever sickness or demons troubling
us or our loved ones can be cured in Jesus name so long we keep that pin
code in our hearts. ‘He makes some poor and others rich; he humbles
some and makes others great (1Samuel 2: 7).’ We have seen what he did
to Job after the devil took all his wealth; left him destitute and struck him
with painful sores. He cured him from his affliction and brought back
twice the wealth he had lost. God never disappoint those who don’t
waver in their faith but believe and patiently wait for him. We have also
seen how he humbled Nebuchadnezzar by driving him away from human
society to live with animals and eat grass.
God answered Daniel’s prayers when he asked God to reveal
Nebuchadnezzar’s dream and its explanation to him. He saved his life and
that of his friends. We hear Daniel when he praised the Lord and said:
‘praise be to the name of God for ever and ever. Wisdom and power is
his. He changes times and seasons. He gives wisdom to the wise and
knowledge to the discerning. He reveals deep and hidden things, he
knows what lies in darkness, and light dwells with him. I thank and praise
you, O God of my father: you have given me power, you have made
66
known to me what we asked of you, and you have made known to us the
dream of the king (Daniel 2: 20-23).’ Daniel’s praise was nothing else but
the truth. God the Almighty did to him what no other god could do. What
king Nebuchadnezzar asked from them was impossible to any mortal
being. That is why the magicians, enchanters, sorcerers and astrologers
failed; and they were all saved by Daniel who was praising the living God.
Jesus said: ‘Then you will know the truth, and the truth will set you
free(John 8:32). God revealed the truth behind Nebuchadnezzar’s dream
to his servant Daniel and as a result all magicians, enchanters, sorcerers
and astrologers were saved from being killed. We should take into
consideration that they were able to perform great miracles during their
time. Unfortunately those miracles could not save them from
Nebuchadnezzar’s wrath. Only the truth from the living God saved them.
He is the only one who ‘reveals deep and hidden things, he knows what
lies in darkness, and light dwells with him.’ Let me remind you that those
false prophets who are practicing witchcraft, witch doctors can perform
miracles but cannot reveal the truth which can save the world from God’s
wrath. Let me add that knowing the truth does not set you free if you
don’t take actions. ‘For it is not those who hear the law who are righteous
in God’s sight, but it is those who obey the law who will be declared
righteous’ (Romans 2:13). It is like in Daniel’s case, if he had kept quit they
would have been killed. To see danger approaching does not save you;
what save you is seeing danger and running to safety. All God’s children
are in safety. They heard the word of God and accepted it and He ‘gave
them the right to become children of God.’ They can now address Him
and say ‘OUR FATHER.’ The almighty God dwell in them. ‘Do you not
know? Have you not heard? The Lord is the everlasting God, the creator
of the ends of the earth. He will not grow tired or weary and increase the
67
power of the weak. Even youths grow tired and weary, and young men
stumble and fall; but those who hope in the Lord will renew their
strength. They will soar on wings like eagles, they will run and not grow
weary, the will walk and not be faint (Isaiah 40: 28-31). Nothing is
impossible to our God Almighty. ‘FOR THINE IS THE KINGDOM; THE
POWER AND THE GLORY.’ THE END
68
CONCLUSION
Thanks for dedicating your time to read these nine Jesus inspired
sermons. You now know the truth. As John 8: 32 says: ‘you will know the
truth, and the truth will set you free.’ Although I agree that the truth can
set you free but I have to add that it is a matter of choice. The truth
cannot set you free if you hear it and reject it. I solemnly advise you to
make your choice instead of following the multitude. The bible say: ‘ go
through the narrow gate, because the gate to hell is wide and the road
that leads to it is easy, and there are many who travel it, But the gate to
life is narrow and the way that leads to it is hard, and there are few
people who find it (Mathew 7: 13).’
Yes! It is true! The way that leads to life is hard. For example, among the
Israelites who were held captive in Babylon, only Shadrach, Meshach,
and Abednego chose the blazing furnace of Nebuchadnezzar than
worshiping idols. How would this evil generation of today be different? I
must also remind you that when God sent the flood only Noah, his wife
and his three sons survived among the whole world because they heed
God’s words. Your fate is in your hands. Whether you choose life or the
second death through the lake burning with fire and Sulphur it is up to
you (Revelation 21: 8). ‘Listen! Says Jesus. I am coming soon! I will bring
my rewards with me, to give to each one according to what he has done.
I am the first and the last, the beginning and the end.
69
